i still don’t quite get how someone who ran a primate research center became a health services expert on drug use?
but what if it was ?
do babies feel shame?
but shame at its core is a cultural/societal/relational construct. naming the societal underpinnings of shame allows someone to view its impact on their life. it’s not an absolution.
what do you mean you didn't find out who their elementary school mascot was?!
best art over a stairwell ever!

yes! just make sure your screening software doesn’t record the total amount of time you spend in the program. if it does, don’t look at it. i know my answer next time someone says ‘want to do a review? it will be fun!’
terrifying and shameful.

it’s not always that simple. falls are hard to predict and depending on the individual they can be devastating. some will chose to limit medications that increase that risk, some will accept the risk. it’s not a simple yes/no in many cases.

for many people, this is an unrealistic proposition. often substance use and trauma are intertwined--saying to someone 'work on the substance first' keeps them out of treatment. we should meet people where they are.

thanks for the heads up, i’ll give it a listen! a quick read of the transcript says they used 400mcg worth of patches or 800mg morphine daily. i think that would scare the bejeezus out of most stateside docs. also makes sense that you’d need a big dose to have it work.

this makes sense when you consider how different the dose ranges for methadone for pain and oud are. maybe fentanyl patches would work as ort if you used big doses, but i don’t see a clinician being comfortable prescribing that.

at least in the population of folks i see with pain and oud, i don’t see this working. just wind up with escalating doses of opioids, early refills and continued relational challenges. could be the pain component, but it seems the addiction ‘overrides’ to some degree. 1/2
frequently the risk isn’t slight. risks/benefits to everything.

'tramadol seen as beneficial nsaid alternative for pain' said no one ever. full agonist opioids increase fall risk too. and comparing to codeine? the question you should be asking yourself is why are you using tramadol or codeine in older adults to begin with.
you don’t? i keep mine stored next to the flux capacitor.

yes! me: 'i have this wonderful medication that will help your nausea' pt: 'great! what is it?' me: 'it is a strong antagonist at the dopamine receptor, and will reduce your nausea' pt: 'ok, but what kind of medicine is it?' me: 'it's well, *whispers* an antipsychotic' pt: pass
good points! i guess i should reframe—does good palliative care ever hurt? it seems like the biggest issue is how do we reach as many people as possible with a limited workforce.
had there ever been a study demonstrating that palliative care doesn’t help folks? when can we simply say ‘when you’re seriously ill, pc helps’.
if that person is a big fan of ayrton senna they will be really disappointed when they need the other stuff.
great work! small change—the jhu cancer study used 1-3mg/70kg and 22-30/70kg. 22/kg would really be mind blowing.
yay!!! well deserved.
are these recorded or broadcast? would love to watch.
very cool. will you be following any pain or functional outcomes as well? inclusion of older adults?
wave as you go by my house!
me too!!
wonderful training. looking forward to hearing your experience.

step 2 cs is a joke. one of my patient actors fell asleep during the clinical encounter and when i checked to see if they were ok, broke character to tell me it wasn’t part of the case. then i thought that must of been part of the case too.

unbelievable to think what began as 12 people in a cambridge backyard two years ago is now this, with a  seminar and  speaking. incredible journey and honored to be tagging along for the trip. – at harvard science center
good luck! i’ve had several colleagues complete the training and it’s been a positive experience.
maybe i should just start a gofundme for my student loans.
i was taught the 50/50 approach as well but it’s definitely a moving target. i think it also matters it the prn is taken sporadically or regularly.  your thoughts?

poignant, but also really disappointing. moreso highlights the failures of our medical system to treat addiction and also the antecedents/sequelae of it. too frequently sud tx is uncoupled from trauma tx and vice versa—instances like this are a stark reminder of our failures.

the equianalgesic tables for bup are not centered on lt opioid dx and less frequently use oral bup for pain, making their application challenging. just like it’s a myth that everyone benefits from lt full agonist opioids, it’s a myth that some pts can’t benefit from bup.

well, that’s not entirely true either. canada refers to it as medical aid in dying, most states/med org have dropped suicide teen from nomenclature. fundamentally they are different—dont compare tx where you remove something versus hastening death by giving a medication.

disagree. use 'thought or wish for hastened death' or something similar. 10-20% of individuals with a terminal illness express a wish for hastened death. expression exists outside of terminal illnesses 2. using suicidal in this context pathologizes a nl emotion/rxn to suffering.
complete misuse of the term and context surrounding suicide/being suicidal.
might i suggest one of these?
i know! i think at the va i could go over the allowed amount and put more patches on, but haven’t had someone i’ve needed to try it on yet.

echo these, and has been effective for older adults on low dose long term opioid therapy who experienced side effects, poor pain control, cognitive impairment, impulsivity. i wish the available dosages were higher as i’d love to see what the limits of use are.
pa prescribed in palliative care setting with approval after patient died. i'm guessing i'm not the only hpm provider who has had this experience.
people who use drugs

also lacking is an appreciation that for the majority of individuals who use drugs, recovery is a natural part. cessation without formal treatment is not frequently discussed or highlighted in psychiatric training. we see a minority of pwud.
you being a jets fan makes a lot of sense
i have learned to check and make sure the bed isn’t wet before you sit down on it.
whoa—thank you for sharing this.
only problem is i would start it, but then get distracted and be left with a huge stack of stickies on the left, and stickies crumpled up in my bag

this is so important--we can do a lot to make the space inviting, warm, and intentional. starts with the lobby, staff, what messages patients see as soon as they arrive. traumainformed primarycarechat

a1: being in the va 1 issue is i in many ways represent a face of an organization that has been complicit in their trauma. sometimes its hard to make it known that the space i'm trying to create is one focused on healing. primarycarechat

i very much prefer this definition as opposed to the criterion a for ptsd. this leaves a lot more room for things that folks experience as traumatic--especially systemic issues like racism, misogyny, etc primarycarechat

zack, palliative care and psychiatry at boston va with some other community work as well. interested in older adults with ptsd and trauma exposure. favorite diner food, definitely breakfast, definitely corned beef and hash. primarycarechat
oh yeah, and i'm really into traumainformed care.
tonight i'll be joining primarycarechat not because i'm a primary care doctor, but i because i'm proud of myself for stopping someone from getting antibiotics for asymptomatic bacteriuria.
loollove this. ! when life gives you lemons...
yep, which is why i feel the debate should be around formulation not the drug itself. though i guess insurance is the only thing stopping someone from putting on multiple butrans patches...
'transdermal buprenorphine in clinical practice - a post-marketing surveillance study in 13179 patients'
also, our use of full agonist opioids long term is based on what we see clinically—not rcts. i am not aware of an rct on opioids that runs longer than a year.
i’m confused, are you considering only rcts as evidence? there was a huge surveillance study like 15 years ago showing bup as a reasonable option for ltot.

also, this discussion leaves out almost 20 years of practical clinical examples in europe of using bup for chronic pain in both cancer and noncancer populations. the conversation shouldn’t be that buprenorphine is ineffective but rather that we have formulation restrictions.

agreed. in what bizarro world do we live in where folks think anyone should work for 27 hours, especially when critical decisions are needed? and the whole 'it's a calling, be grateful' thing is bogus. if i had to work 27 hour shifts, i'd pick another job.

i love getting these—i practice hpm but my cohort is psychiatrists so i really look like an outlier. i’m hoping if i come in 1st i get a prize. what really irks me is they don’t ever calculate the daily oral morphine equivalent correctly.

totally agree with you. i think the chronic inflammatory cycle plays a big role. you've essentially nailed the premise of 'when the body says no' by . then in dementia you have difficulty in repressing emotions, coupled with normal aging process of life review=trouble
ice cream recs: christina’s in inman sq, picco in south end, fomu. notimeisbadforicecream. also you make it to trillium brewery?
let me know next time, i work weds and thurs nights so tough to get out during the week. enjoy pcep!
i am, how long are you in town? and where is pcep?

3/3 certainly i think standard trauma informed approaches to care benefit all, with or without trauma exposure, and especially in dementia care, which can often become dehumanizing as the disease progresses. it's too easy to think of the person as 'not there'. tic might help.

also dementia is a disease of aging, and aces accelerate that. so should we really be thinking about aces in early dementia folks? maybe a framework is the folks with aces that made it to old age show more resilience--can that be something we focus on rather than the trauma. 2/

a couple of things come to mind--certainly the connection with ptsd and dementia in veteran populations, but i'm not sure what drives it, simply traumatic exposure or something unique to vet experience? if former then you'd think it would be generalizable to other populations. 1/
helmand is great. check out: sarma, coppa, shore leave, craigie on main, and ganko ittetsu for ramen.
wonderful read. and definitely worth following that with ‘trauma and recovery’ by judith herman—which influenced bessels work.
picture is worth a thousand words though!
you must be a lot of fun at parties
yay! love seeing intersection of hpm and addiction medicine.
stuff in the notch starting to fill in yet?
congrats!!
highlights how both the clinician and patient often feel like they are doing something they aren’t comfortable with. navigating that is really tough.

i do think there is a problem with the word ‘force’. it would appear that the tx plan js dangerous and not accomplishing functional improvement. i wouldnt say ‘i’m going to force you off amlodipine and onto something else bc you’re still hypertensive’
you’re right—we can use psychedelics for all the other ones, of course.

i encounter this sometimes in palliative care, and with relatively few cases to go on, rotating to bup(either suboxone or butrans in some cases) was helpful. there is sometimes questionable underlying oud that is hard to parse out as well.

this for me is the weirdest thing about palliative care—why do we restrict illness types? i get it for programs based at a cancer center, but always struck me as odd for academic or community hospitals.

palliative care provided at the brigham is through dfci, which likely creates a barrier to having outpatients with other diseases. bidmc outpatient doesn’t have illness restrictions, other than being ‘life limiting’. lahey clinic might be an option as well.
my thoughts exactly! hapc

this interdisciplinary fellowship has been an instrumental part of my training, allowing me to develop research skills, provide space for reflection and grow into the clinician i wish to be. hope folks in palliative hpm and hapc consider it too.
as you should be! amazing work.
even the doggos seem distressed at the tile job.

our palliative care program is looking for a social worker to join our outpatient team! you'd work with a great group that really values a diversity of perspectives and sees patients across the continuum of illness, not just cancer. https://www.usajobs.gov/getjob/viewdetails/551963800 hapc hpm swhpn
positive regard, warmth, genuineness...carl rogers is proud!
great thread!

misuse is such a loaded term—who defines it? misuse looks different in different people at different times causing different issues. at the very least ‘misuse’ is better than ‘pseudoaddiction’ as a term.
yay! getting waivered and caring for these folks has been an amazing journey. glad you’re embarking.
also email palliativebuprenorphine.com to be a part of our upcoming clinician support group! capcseminar19
i’m feeling quite jealous of all the folks at gsa2019 capcseminar19 and istss2019. living vicariously through all these wonderful threads.
such a rockstar!
absolutely! email your contact info to the address above and we will make sure you’re on the list.
our first call to discuss plans for the group will be on 11/21 at 3pm est. email to receive an invite.

are you a hpm clinician using buprenorphine in your practice? have an x waiver but unsure what to do next? looking to better serve seriously ill patients with oud? if so, join our clinician support group! email palliativebuprenorphine.com for more info.

disagree. the article was in a palliative and hospice journal, talking explicitly about end of life. again, treating someone without factoring in their lived experience is poor care. for some, that means a discussion about the impact of their sud.
last time i checked, we haven’t solved the problem of mortality, so not sure what you mean. if you’ve found a way to live forever please share it with me so we can market it and retire.
literature is full of case reports of ‘bad trips’, frequently in setting of mixed use with other substances. minimal reports of bad trips or adverse events when used in therapeutic setting.
this approach also makes me think what are other important things to put in the social history to help quantify health inequity—should we be adding zip code?

i’m open minded and my clinical experience with patients in hpm has been that cannabis is enjoyable for some, and has some focused benefits, but isn’t a panacea or opioid replacement. i do see orthostasis and falls which is particularly worrisome for my geriatrics pts.

if you are at idconf19 and care for rural vets or are a rural clinician, we want to talk to you! come by the  table by registration to talk a bit about what your educational needs are when caring for rural vets with ptsd. we want to help.   – at gaylord palms resort & convention center
great to see trauma across the lifespan being recognized at idconf19. starts with aces all the way through later adulthood trauma reengagement/loss. hpm palliativecare hospice geriatrics

if folks want to try it, go ahead, at the least it smells nice and feels like you’re doing something for yourself. i’ll sometimes have a patient who thinks it’s amazing. i sometimes use a salve for my lower back, but it’s also got arnica and other stuff in it.

jackson bound for the aahpm kathy foley research retreat! couldn’t be more excited, and couldn’t be a more different trip than the last time i was in jackson.
telling people i’m a palliative care clinician provides responses that are waaaaaay less bizarre than telling people i’m a psychiatrist.
